title: 103_s1013
content: The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" is cited in this section, which amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It addresses the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to address the estate tax treatment of land subject to a qualified conservation easement. If the executor elects, the value of such land (minus any debt) can be excluded from the gross estate. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude the value of land subject to a qualified conservation easement from the gross estate for estate tax purposes. The land must be located near a metropolitan area or national park, owned by the decedent or their family for three years prior to death, and meet specific criteria set by the Secretary. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude the value of land subject to a qualified conservation easement from the gross estate for estate tax purposes. The land must be owned by the decedent or a family member for three years before death and meet specific criteria for a qualified conservation contribution. The term 'family member' is defined as per section 2032A(e)(2). The additional estate tax is imposed on the first person disposing of property with a retained development right after the decedent's death. The amount of tax is based on the increase in estate tax liability that would have occurred. The additional estate tax is imposed on the person disposing of property with a retained development right after the decedent's death. The tax amount is based on the increase in estate tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been included in the gross estate of the decedent. If only a portion of the property is disposed of, the person pays a pro rata portion of the tax, which can be reduced for subsequent dispositions. The tax imposed on the person disposing of property with a retained development right is due by April 15 of the following year. A development right refers to the right to use property for commercial purposes not directly supportive of conservation. The tax imposed on property with a retained development right is due by April 15 of the following year. The election to use the land for farming, forestry, ranching, horticulture, viticulture, or recreation must be made on the estate tax return and is irrevocable once chosen. The executor making the election must calculate the additional estate tax and file a 'Notice of Potential Estate Tax Due' in the locality where the land is located. The computation and filing must be done as prescribed by the Secretary. Additionally, the basis of property acquired from a decedent is amended. The basis of property acquired from a decedent is amended to include property excluded from the gross estate under certain conditions. These amendments apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, including land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after that date. Gift tax on land subject to a qualified conservation easement. Gift Tax With Respect to Land Subject to a Qualified Conservation Easement: An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a provision where the transfer of land with a qualified conservation easement may not be considered a taxable gift. If the donor retains any development rights, an additional gift tax is imposed. An additional gift tax is imposed if the donor retains any development rights when transferring land with a qualified conservation easement. The tax amount is based on the increase in gift tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been treated as a gift. The amendments made by this section apply to gifts of land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992. SEC. 4 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for qualified conservation contributions where surface and mineral rights are separated. It states that if the probability of surface mining on the property is remote, the contribution requirements are met. The amendment applies to contributions made after December 31, 1992. SEC. 5 clarifies that a qualified conservation contribution is not considered a disposition. Qualified conservation contributions by gift or otherwise are not considered a disposition for tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code. Land subject to a qualified conservation easement is not disqualified as qualified real property. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a paragraph stating that property with a qualified conservation easement is still considered qualified real property. These amendments apply to estates of decedents who die after December 31, 1992, with land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after the same date.
